L2_gloss:
young lady
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 1. Abalone”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Carórił hiwót.Abalone was a young woman.

dentalium
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 1. Abalone”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Dók buhráł, thígadił. Diníh.In the north, however, was a young man. He was a dentalium.

ear shell, abalone
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 1. Abalone”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Carórił hiwót.Abalone was a young woman.
Affirmative answer to a question; yes

Used to form nouns denoting the goal of a verb.
‎bíw- (“to eat”) + ‎-ih → ‎bíwih (“food”)

old man
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 1. Abalone”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Kokwíł tòkw.The old man was home.

owl
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 3. Owl”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Kukwe ku tólih phicúhlokš hi wisapalí.In the old days the owl was going to marry at home.

sturgeon
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 56. Fish roe.”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Póhm wasadáhl, póhm.A sturgeon's roe, a sturgeon['s].

young man
1964,  Della Prince,  “Text 1. Abalone”, in Karl V. Teeter, The Wiyot Language, University of California press:Dók buhráł, thígadił.In the north, however, was a young man.
roe (especially of a salmon), 1964,  Della Prince,
